r:Description.r:Content: Populations

The mother, partner and their study children with an Estimated Due Date of between 1st April 1991 and 31st December 1992 born in the administrative county of Avon as defined at the time of recruitment.

The mother and partner of study babies aged 8 weeks gestation to 12 months, with an Estimated Due Date of between 1st April 1991 and 31st December 1992 and living in the administrative county of Avon as defined at the time of recruitment.

The mother, partner and their study children aged 60 to 155 months with an Estimated Due Date of between 1st April 1991 and 31st December 1992 born in the administrative county of Avon as defined at the time of recruitment.
The mother and their study children aged 156-227 months with an EDD of between 1st April 1991 and 31st December 1992 born in the administrative county of Avon as defined at the time of recruitment.

The mother, partner and study son/daughter aged 228-371 months with an EDD of between 1st April 1991 and 31st December 1992 born in the administrative county of Avon as defined at the time of recruitment.
All babies (alive or dead) after the 24th week of gestation in one particular week in 1970 in the United Kingdom.
All children born on a particular week in 1970 in Great Britain or who, having been born in that week elsewhere, emigrated to Great Britain.
All children born in one particular week in 1970 in Great Britain or who, having been born in that week elsewhere, emigrated to Great Britain.
All children born in one particular week in 1970 in Great Britain or who, having been born in that week elsewhere, emigrated to Great Britain.
All children born in one particular week in 1970 in Great Britain or who, having been born in that week elsewhere, emigrated to Great Britain before their 16th birthday.
All children born in one particular week in 1970 in Great Britain or who, having been born in that week elsewhere, emigrated to Great Britain before their 16th birthday.

All children born in one particular week in 1970 in Great Britain or who, having been born in that week elsewhere, emigrated to Great Britain before their 16th birthday, less those who died, refused or had not taken part since the ten-year follow-up.

All those born in one particular week in April 1970 in Great Britain or, who having been born that week elsewhere, emigrated to Great Britain before their 16th birthday and who had either taken part in one of the previous two sweeps (in 2004 and 2000) or who had personally confirmed their address or who had been traced.

All those born in one particular week in April 1970 in Great Britain or, who having been born that week elsewhere, emigrated to Great Britain before their 16th birthday and who had either taken part in one of the previous two sweeps (in 2008 and 2004) or who had confirmed their address before 2004 or who had been traced.
All those born, including still births, in one particular week in April 1970 until they die or permanently emigrate from Great Britain.

The COVID-19 Survey Wave 1 involved participants from the 1970 British Cohort Study. Invitations to participate in Wave 1 were sent via email to all those for whom an email address was held, including emigrants, but not including those who have permanently withdrawn from the studies, died or been defined as 'permanently untraced'.
Men and women born in Hertfordshire between 1931 and 1939 who were still resident and registered with a GP in Hertfordshire in the 1990s.
All births in Hertfordshire between 1931 and 1939 for people who were still resident and registered with a GP in Hertfordshire in the 1990's.
A stratified sample of babies born between 1 September 2000 and 31 August 2001 in England and Wales, and 23 November 2000 and 11 January 2002 in Scotland and Northern Ireland.

The COVID-19 Survey Wave 1 involved participants from the Millennium Cohort Study (born 2000-02). Invitations to participate in Wave 1 were sent via email to all those for whom an email address was held, including emigrants, but not including those who have permanently withdrawn from the studies, died or been defined as 'permanently untraced'. In the case of MCS, invitations were sent to cohort members and parents. MCS parents were only invited to participate if they had taken part in the last major wave of the study - the Age 17 Survey (MCS7).
All babies born during a single week in 1958, and all still births or infants dying before the age of 28 days within a three month period around the chosen week.
All children born in Great Britain during a single week in 1958 or who, having been born elsewhere, migrated to Great Britain.
All children born in Great Britain during a single week in 1958, or who, having been born elsewhere, migrated to Great Britain.
All children born in Great Britain during a single week in 1958, or who, having been born elsewhere, migrated to Great Britain.
All cohort members who had participated in at least one of the NCDS follow-ups.
All cohort members; any husband, wife, or cohabitee; from the natural or adopted children of 1 in 3 cohort families; and from the mother of these children.
All cohort members who had ever participated in NCDS, less those who had died, permanently refused or emigrated.
12,037 cohort members who responded to the Age 23 Survey (NCDS4), Age 33 Survey (NCDS5) or Age 42 Survey (NCDS6).
All cohort members who had participated in at least one NCDS sweep since 1981, less those who had refused, died or emigrated.
All cohort members who had participated in at least one NCDS sweep since Age 42, confirmed their address since 2000 or for whom a recent address had been traced.
All cohort members who had participated in any of the last three surveys or had confirmed their address since 2000.

The COVID-19 Survey Wave 1 involved participants from the 1958 National Child Development Study. Invitations to participate in Wave 1 were sent via email to all those for whom an email address was held, including emigrants, but not including those who have permanently withdrawn from the studies, died or been defined as 'permanently untraced'.
A sample of the original infants.
All women who delivered during a single week in March 1946.
All eligible female study members.
13,687 births recorded in England, Scotland and Wales during March 1946
All eligible study members.

All 'premature' babies (birth weight 5.5lbs or less) born in a single week in March 1946 and a set of controls from the same or nearby local health authority areas and matched for sex, birth order, maternal age, social class and other unspecified social circumstances
The schools of all eligible study members.
Administrators of further and technical education establishments at which cohort members were students.

Participants from the MRC National Survey of Health and Development. The invitation was initially sent to participates via email to all those for whom an email address was held, including emigrants, but not including those who have permanently withdrawn from the study, died or been defined as 'permanently untraced'. A follow-up letter was then sent to all participants whom a postal addresses was held and whom had no email address, but not including those who emigrants, have permanently withdrawn from the study, died or been defined as 'permanently untraced'.

A stratified sample of young people who were in Year 9 in English state and independent schools and pupil referral units in February 2004. Cohort members were born between 1 September 2000 and 31 August 2001 in England and Wales, and 23 November 2000 and 11 January 2002 in Scotland and Northern Ireland
A stratified sample of young people who were in Year 9 in English state and independent schools and pupil referral units in February 2004.
All cohort members who were in Year 9 in English state and independent schools and pupil referral units in February 2004 and who participated at sweep 1.
All cohort members who were in Year 9 in English state and independent schools and pupil referral units in February 2004 and who participated at sweep 2.

All cohort members who were in Year 9 in English state and independent schools and pupil referral units in February 2004 and who participated at sweep 3. In addition, the sweep 4 sample frame included an ethnic minority boost.
All cohort members who were in Year 9 in English state and independent schools and pupil referral units in February 2004 and who participated at sweep 4.
All cohort members who were in Year 9 in English state and independent schools and pupil referral units in February 2004 and who participated at sweep 5.
All cohort members who were in Year 9 in English state and independent schools and pupil referral units in February 2004 and who participated at sweep 6.
All cohort members who were in Year 9 in English state and independent schools and pupil referral units in February 2004 and who participated at a previous sweep.

The COVID-19 Survey Wave 1 involved participants from the Next Steps study (born 1989-90). Invitations to participate in Wave 1 were sent via email to all those for whom an email address was held, including emigrants, but not including those who have permanently withdrawn from the studies, died or been defined as 'permanently untraced'.
Women resident in Southampton aged 20 to 34 years and their subsequent children

Women resident in Southampton aged 20 to 34 years who had participated in the initial interview phase of the SWS and reported they had become pregnant and gave birth and the child had reached 12 months of age.

Women resident in Southampton aged 20 to 34 years had participated in the initial interview phase of the SWS , reported they had become pregnant and gave birth and the child had reached 24 months of age.

Women resident in Southampton aged 20 to 34 years had participated in the initial interview phase of the SWS , reported they had become pregnant and gave birth and the child had reached 3 years of age.

Women resident in Southampton aged 20 to 34 years who had participated in the initial interview phase of the SWS and reported they had become pregnant and gave birth and the child had reached 6 months of age.
Women resident in Southampton aged 20 to 34 years
Women resident in Southampton aged 20 to 34 years who had participated in the initial interview phase of the SWS and reported they had become pregnant and gave birth.
Women resident in Southampton aged 20 to 34 years who had participated in the initial interview phase of the SWS and reported they had become pregnant.
UK residential population in 2009-10
UK residential population in 2009-10
UK residential population in 2010-11
UK residential population in 2011-12
UK residential population in 2012-13
UK residential population in 2012-13
UK residential population in 2014-15
Mothers, their partners and their first born children that were born between 2007 and 2009, who had their 20 week scan at Arrowe Park Hospital, Wirral.
First time mothers, their partners and subsequently their child, who attended for antenatal care at Arrowe Park Hospital, Wirral, between February 2007 and October 2008.
WCHADS mother recruited into our intensive subsample - stratified for psychosocial risk
WCHADS extensive sample (includes intensive subsample)- antenatal and birth outcomes
WCHADS mother recruited into our intensive subsample and their infants - stratified for psychosocial risk
WCHADS extensive sample (includes intensive subsample) - mothers
WCHADS mother recruited into our intensive subsample and their infants - stratified for psychosocial risk
WCHADS extensive sample - mothers and partners
WCHADS mother recruited into our intensive subsample and their infants - stratified for psychosocial risk
WCHADS mother recruited into our intensive subsample and their child - stratified for psychosocial risk
WCHADS extensive sample (includes intensive subsample) - mother, child and partner
WCHADS mother recruited into our intensive subsample and their child - stratified for psychosocial risk
WCHADS extensive sample - mothers and partners
WCHADS extensive sample (includes intensive subsample) - mothers, partners and child
WCHADS extensive sample (includes intensive subsample) - mothers, partners and child
ALSPAC Populations

The mother and partner of study children aged 13 to 19 months with an Estimated Due Date of between 1st April 1991 and 31st December 1992 born in the administrative county of Avon as defined at the time of recruitment.
BCS70 Populations
HCS Populations
MCS Populations
NCDS Populations

15,770 households were included at Sweep 1. At Sweep 4, 352 ethnic boost interviews were added, taking the total number of cohort members who had taken part to 16,122. The study population consists of young people who were in Year 9 in English state and independent schools and pupil referral units in February 2004. Cohort members were born between 1st September 1989 and 31st August 1990.
NSHD Populations
SWS Populations
Understanding Society Populations
UK residential population in 2020 who have participated in at least one of the last two waves of Understanding Society data collection.
WCHADS Populations
